headline.seo: Breast-Feeding Supplies Win Tax Break From I.R.S.
headline.print_headline: Breast Milk Supplies Win Tax Breaks From I.R.S.
headline.main: Breast-Feeding Supplies Win Tax Breaks From I.R.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: The I.R.S. reversed itself, deciding to allow nursing mothers a tax break on pumps and other breast-feeding supplies.
docs.snippet: The I.R.S. reversed itself, deciding to allow nursing mothers a tax break on pumps and other breast-feeding supplies.

docs.abstract: More young people and adults in their 30s and 40s are being hospitalized for stroke even as stroke rates are dropping in older people, new data show.
docs.lead_paragraph: More young people and adults in their 30s and 40s are being hospitalized for stroke, even as stroke rates are dropping in older people, new data show.
docs.snippet: More young people and adults in their 30s and 40s are being hospitalized for stroke even as stroke rates are dropping in older people, new data show.

headline.seo: New York Race Directors Raise Concern Over Proposed Police Fee
headline.print_headline: Proposed Police Fee Is Concern for Race Directors
headline.main: Race Directors Raise Concern Over Proposed Police Fee

byline.original: By KEN BELSON and LIZ ROBBINS

docs.lead_paragraph: Organizers of the New York City Marathon and dozens of other races that use city streets say that a new fee sought by the police could significantly drive up their costs.
docs.snippet: Organizers of the New York City Marathon and dozens of other races that use city streets say that a new fee sought by the police could significantly drive up their costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the news: Early surgery, obesity and a breast cancer shake-up. Test your knowledge of this weeks’ health news.
docs.snippet: In the news: Early surgery, obesity and a breast cancer shake-up. Test your knowledge of this weeks’ health news.

docs.abstract: Some of the material I read before writing my latest column.
docs.lead_paragraph: The comments so far on my Opinionator piece today are lively and engaging enough to keep you entertained for a bit, but if you're interested in seeing some of the material I read before writing the column, here it is, with comments of my own.
docs.snippet: Some of the material I read before writing my latest column.

docs.abstract: President Obama summons House Republican leaders for lunch, while conservatives prepare to take stock of the Republican field in the 2012 presidential race.
docs.snippet: President Obama summons House Republican leaders for lunch, while conservatives prepare to take stock of the Republican field in the 2012 presidential race.

headline.seo: Michelle Obama to Take Anti-Obesity Program Global
headline.print_headline: First Lady Is Taking Anti-Obesity Initiative Global
headline.main: First Lady Taking Health Work Global

docs.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama said she intended to spend part of the coming year shaping a more international message, with a possible focus on issues of maternal and child health as well as obesity.
docs.snippet: Michelle Obama said she intended to spend part of the coming year shaping a more international message, with a possible focus on issues of maternal and child health as well as obesity.

headline.main: Timing of Baby Food Tied to Obesity Risk

docs.abstract: Formula-fed babies who start eating solid food before they are 4 months old are six times more likely to be obese by age 3, a new study shows.
docs.lead_paragraph: Feeding an infant solid food before 4 months of age increases the baby's risk of becoming obese by the toddler years, a new study shows.
docs.snippet: Formula-fed babies who start eating solid food before they are 4 months old are six times more likely to be obese by age 3, a new study shows.

headline.print_headline: CHILDHOOD: When the Cafeteria Line Leads to Tater Tots

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of more than 1,000 sixth graders in Michigan found that those who regularly had the school lunch were 29 percent more likely to be obese than those who brought lunch from home.
docs.snippet: A study of more than 1,000 sixth graders in Michigan found that those who regularly had the school lunch were 29 percent more likely to be obese than those who brought lunch from home.
